review: I currently work at an advertising agency, the Creative Director and I were discussing Mad Men and he told me I had to read this book because it captuI currently work at an advertising agency, the Creative Director and I were discussing Mad Men and he told me I had to read this book because it captures Advertising entirely.... needless to say this book was ridiculously on point! The book was written in 2000 so it is a little outdated, but it still manages to capture what it is like working at an advertising agency. The book is written in email correspondence amongst the worker at a fictional agency. When I just started reading, it took awhile for me to get use to the names and title of each email sender but 10% in I knew their personality hands down. I thought it would have been hard for a writer to full capture the personality of the email senders via email but Beaumont did an exceptional job. As one er said, this book wont win a Nobel prize but it will keep you laughing out loud. A fast, hilarious look into the advertising world! ...more

title: Stillhouse Lake        (Stillhouse Lake, #1)
author: Caine, Rachel
my rating: 1 of 5 stars2 of 5 stars3 of 5 stars4 of 5 stars5 of 5 starsadd to shelves
review: I wont lie, this book is very fast paced, and easy to read- I finished it in a day. The first half of the book was thrilling and will keep you entertaI wont lie, this book is very fast paced, and easy to read- I finished it in a day. The first half of the book was thrilling and will keep you entertained, the second half was basically a cookie cutter ending. If you have read any "psychological thriller" you've read the ending of this book. I could have read the end with my eyes closed and still know what happened. I try not to dwell on the bad because I have no idea how hard it is to write a book but there are two things that stood out that really made me dislike this book. 1. The author wants us to believe the improbable, she wants to believe that Gina who was married to her husband for over 10 years never once stepped foot in his garage/work area. The entire plot is based on us believing this absurd idea. How are you living in a house together and never once did you think to check out the area where your husband works? How did the kids not randomly end up there? I just don't get how Caine would like us to believe that didn't happen. 2. The "cliffhanger" was such a rip off, literally. I get that not every question will be answered at the end of a book but to knowingly end the book like that is low blow. I for one will not be reading the next book in this series. I am really trying not to nit pick but those two factors really threw off the entire book for me, especially the ending. It was such a cop out on Caine's part. ...more

I know it takes a lot to write novel, I know it is hard work but I just did not like this and with all the hype around it, everything fell flat for me. The characters were one dimensional, predictable and borderline clichés. The plot was entirely predictable and idiot proof to say the least. There are certain revelations that I honestly felt was common sense. How do you not know exactly where your husband is at every Tuesdays and Thursdays for the last three years? How blindly trusting do you have to be? This is the thing, when a book gets high ratings and keeps showing up on my timeline I expect a lot and I was very disappointed. Last, as on Reviewer puts it, a lot of the scenes in the book were ridiculous, here you have a fully pregnant woman fighting off her attacker and going through the most stressful pregnancy. Why was she even pregnant to begin with? That added nothing to the overall story/plot progression. The novel set in the UK and it is about a family that has to be quarantined for seven days over the Christmas period. Yes, I was reading a book about Christmas, in July... good way to get the Christmas spirit started. It might just be the thought of having the spend seven days in quarantine with my family, but this novel did not do it for me. It felt like one of those books you've read already. Honestly, the plot felt very vanilla and already done, not that anything is wrong with that, but if you're going to do safe, at least make it less predictable. The characters were generic and clichéd some borderline annoying after 5 chapters. What I will say is this, if you are looking for an easy, laid-back holiday read this Christmas, this book is right up your alley. title: How Not to Die: Discover the Foods Scientifically Proven to Prevent and Reverse Disease
author: Greger, Michael*
my rating: 1 of 5 stars2 of 5 stars3 of 5 stars4 of 5 stars5 of 5 starsadd to shelves
review: On Monday my friend told me to watch the Netflix Documentary  "What the Health"  and needless to say watching that changed my life... yes I know its jOn Monday my friend told me to watch the Netflix Documentary  "What the Health"  and needless to say watching that changed my life... yes I know its just been four days but I have been making changes. The Netflix documentary and this book basically stand on the same premise, how to change your life by eating a whole food plant based diet. After watching the documentary I wanted to learn more about the plant based diet and how to go about making the changes. This book delve into that along with many other topics. It is clear Greger is an authority on this topic and the presentation of the research was done in a clear and engaging way. What stood out most for me was not only the evidence that Greger put forward that substantiated all his claims but how in-depth he went in making sure the readers understand the topic. I am trying to make the changes to a plant based diet but I want to make informed decisions and this book helped a lot. The second part of the book, really holds your hands and shows you exactly the steps you need to transition to a plant based diet. I know I am gushing and going on and on about this, but I feel everyone is responsible for their health and how they feel, this book shows you in no uncertain terms how you can improve your health by making small daily changes. Last, at lot of people will become overwhelmed and think they cant do it, but Greger reinforces in his book that this is not a one size fit all plan. You are allowed to make daily/weekly/monthly steps to reach a more plant based, whole food lifestyle change. He also pointed out that it is ok to indulge on special occasions, there are no hard and fast rules. This is a just a great read for your health and if you decide to move forward with a lifestyle change. ...more

review: Coming off the heels of an amazing read, ,"The Seven Husband of Evelyn Hugo" I decided to give Reid another go and read one of her novels- I was that Coming off the heels of an amazing read, ,"The Seven Husband of Evelyn Hugo" I decided to give Reid another go and read one of her novels- I was that impressed with "The Seven Husband of Evelyn Hugo".You remember when you were young and you used to read those Goosebumps books where you get to decide on how the story goes? Where if you want to stay you flip to page #3, if you want to leave you flip to page #25 etc...  Maybe In Another Life  is the grown up, chick-lit version of those Goosebumps books. I guess this books works and gets a really high rating because it is human nature to want to know the "what if". What if we hadn't made that decision, what if we had said yes instead of no? And cudos to Reid, for exploring those decisions in this way. I have to hand it to her, this is a great twist on an otherwise boring story. What I didn't really appreciation was how predicable everything turned out. There were a lot of repetition and I had to wonder how often I would have to read the same stories. I felt Reid could have pushed herself to make it less repetitive. But a good attempt over all, the writing was engaging, even though the characters were a little whiny and annoying at time. If you are looking for fun, fluffy chick-lit read, you've found it! ...more

title: Little Fires Everywhere
author: Ng, Celeste*
my rating: 1 of 5 stars2 of 5 stars3 of 5 stars4 of 5 stars5 of 5 starsadd to shelves
review: *Updated September 2, 2019* I decided to re-read  Little Fires Everywhere  two years after reading it the first time because I read that it was being *Updated September 2, 2019* I decided to re-read  Little Fires Everywhere  two years after reading it the first time because I read that it was being made into a series. Also I wanted to see if I didn't necessarily liked it because it was so hyped up. I can say, with a little time and re-read I did enjoy reading the book a second time around- so much so, I increased my rating to 4 stars.  *Reviewed October 2017*  I have been anxiously waiting Celeste Ng second novel. I got so nervous when I picked it up to read because I really wanted to love this book. I wanted this to be the book I gushed and told everyone about for 2017. Needless to say, I was somewhat disappointed and confused, I felt let down, as if something was missing and I cant exactly put my finger on it.  Little Fires Everywhere  is set in Shaker Heights, where everything is perfect and uniformed, even the lawns. We are introduced to the Richardson family- a complex group of individuals who lives in comfort and lacks nothing. The family rents an apartment, and their new tent is Mia and her daughter Pearl. The book, for the most part, covers the relationship between the Richardson and their tenant, among other things. While this was an enjoyable read, I cannot tell you exactly what the book is about. For the most part, it felt like.... "little plots everywhere" (lol). I understand the need for backstory and sub-plots but there were so many in this novel that it sometime felt as if it was taking away from the main plot. Also, when you have characters in the sub-plot that seem more interesting in the main plot, that's a little problem. I just felt the book was a little all over the place and didn't really hone in much on the main plot. Also, the actions of some of the characters seemed a little far-fetched, even for fiction, but that might just have been me. Overall, while I am a little underwhelmed, I have to say it was an enjoyable read, I was just expecting a lot more....more

I have a fascination with this country so reading a story set there. As you can see, I really wanted to love this book but it felt short in certain areas for me. The characters Beauty and Robin were very colourful. I loved how the author portrayed them as strong and brave women. However, I felt a lot was lacking in terms of the focus of the plot, too much was happening and too fast. I would have loved to read novel that was about Beauty, how she came to be a teacher and what her sons were like. At certain points I questioned Robin's voice which fluctuated between a 10 year old's voice and a 25 year old voice. There is also the ending which I felt was entirely too rushed, very unbelievable and at some points eye-rolling. The author really lost me at the last 100 pages. I must say, this was a good debut and I am looking forward to Marais's sophomore work. ...more

title: Uninvited: Living Loved When You Feel Less Than, Left Out, and Lonely
author: TerKeurst, Lysa*
my rating: 1 of 5 stars2 of 5 stars3 of 5 stars4 of 5 stars5 of 5 starsadd to shelves
review: Solid 3.5 I liked this book a lot, this is a book that I will re-read or reference a lot in the coming year. While the book sometimes feel a little alSolid 3.5 I liked this book a lot, this is a book that I will re-read or reference a lot in the coming year. While the book sometimes feel a little all over the place and there is a lot of repeating in some areas- I really enjoyed the take away messages. TerKeurst knows how to connect to her readers, and her writing style makes it an easy read. One of my favorite chapters in this book was Chapter 11: Ten Things You Must Remember When Rejected . As a Christian that is early in my walk, this chapter really spoke to me in so many ways. Specifically the sections that encourages us to not ask the "what" questions, not the "why" question. We go through so many trials and troubles in life and this chapter offers practical advice on how to really face these hard and difficult challenges. TerKeurst listed some questions we should ask in these times: 1. What is one good thing I’ve learned from this?2. What was a downside to this situation that I can be thankful is no longer my burden to carry?3. What were the unrealistic expectations I had, and how can I better manage these next time?4. What do I need to do to boost my courage to pursue future opportunities?5. What is one positive change I could make in my attitude about the future?6. What are some lingering negative feelings about this situation that I need to pray through and shake off to be better prepared to move forward?7. What is one thing God has been asking me to do today to make tomorrow easier? I have this list written out, and it so good to have on hard and really go through when life gets rough and you are tempted to ask the "why" questions. A great read for those who want to know more about Jesus, how to real with rejection and how to develop a closer relationship with God. ...more

title: This Is Just My Face: Try Not to Stare
author: Sidibe, Gabourey
my rating: 1 of 5 stars2 of 5 stars3 of 5 stars4 of 5 stars5 of 5 starsadd to shelves
review: Wow! What an engaging, delightful, surprising read- I devoured this book in a day, that is how enjoyable this book was. Gabourey (NOT GABBY!) Sidibe iWow! What an engaging, delightful, surprising read- I devoured this book in a day, that is how enjoyable this book was. Gabourey (NOT GABBY!) Sidibe is best known for her roles in Precious, The Big C, Empire  etc. I first saw her when she starred in Precious and then after in Empire. I wouldn't call myself a big fan, and I am usually not one for young celebrities writing memoirs, it usually comes off as shallow and self-absorbed- most of what they have the say doesn't add to the conversation and is usually eyerolling- that wasn't the case with Garbourey. I absolutely loved how real Garourey was in her book, This is Just My Face: Try Not to Stare . After finishing this novel I felt like we were besties- no lie, I actually started following her on twitter so we can talk (lol). I am a sucker for a great title and book cover, this was backed up a thoroughly enjoyable, insightful read. I loved how the book felt like a conversation, I actually read the entire novel in my head using Gabourey's voice. Its great when you get just a raw look at how fame changes people and those around them, one of the things that stood out for me was how much was expected of her after her first role in Precious, how things remained the same and she showed up to red carpets in less than spectacular wardrobe. Another was how mean and rude people can be, she spoke about how people felt the need to give her health advice in the most obnoxious way. Honestly, no memoir gets any realer like this. Gabourey KEEPS. IT. REAL. and keeps you laughing out loud in the process. This is definitely a must read for me! I am now a big fan and twitter follower. ...more

review: "Orphan Train transported a reported two hundred thousand children from the East Coast to the Midwest between 1854 and 1929." Things I did not know.  "Orphan Train transported a reported two hundred thousand children from the East Coast to the Midwest between 1854 and 1929." Things I did not know. I am a huge fan of historical fiction, especially when there historical part is something I have never heard or known about. Today I found out about the Orphan Train and it has got to be the most saddest discovery I have read about in awhile. Basically these orphans were gathered up and taken to the Midwest to be "auctioned" off or used for laborers- what a sad state. While Kline did bring a pretty much unknown topic to the forefront with her book, I felt execution, character development, plot and writing fell way below expectation. The book read like a YA- no offense to YA novels/writers, but it was laced with clichéd . To put it another way, the book felt safe, shallow and barely scratched the surface of the tragedy of the Orphan Train. I cant say how much research went into this book, but overall it felt lacking. I get so angry when I read a book with a great premise that fails because of execution and that is exactly what happened here. Kline, should have stepped out of her comfort zoom a lot more to write a book that was filled with depth....more

review: Astounding, exceptional- all of the stars and then some! " Sometimes life doesn't let you choose your battles, just the company you keep.""The only t Astounding, exceptional- all of the stars and then some! " Sometimes life doesn't let you choose your battles, just the company you keep.""The only time I'm not moving forward is when I'm taking aim." Have you ever read a book that you transports you to another world- in this case Beartown. Where you feel like you are submerged and you have to remember to come up for air because you are so immersed into the book, the characters, the plot that you never want to leave. Where the real world doesn't exist, the only thing that exist is the world created by that author. Have you ever read a book like that? If you do decide to read Beartown, that's exactly how you will feel. It is clear that Fredrik Backman knows how to the the most mundane situation and make them interesting. While the premise is based on the sport of Hockey, it is important to note that there is more to the book than that. It is about the fans, the players, the board, the coaches, the parents, a town and how all of those elements come together and collides in the most ugly and beautiful of ways. I cannot remember the last time I read a book that really stuck with me, I was up so late and so early making sure I finished it. I went to sleep and dreamt about it, I was doing my usual runs and I could not get the book out of my mind. Beartown is a must read, it is Fredik Backman at his best and finest....more

review: How do you know a book is book? After five years of reading it, you are still enraged by what happened. I have been dying to get my hand on this book How do you know a book is book? After five years of reading it, you are still enraged by what happened. I have been dying to get my hand on this book because every time I open my Goodreads page, I see it popping up.  Stay With Me  Is a story about Yejide and Akin- a Nigerian Couple whose marriage is crumbling because of infertility, lack of communication, the family meddling in the marriage and overall secrecy. This is a very strong debut novel, Adebayo, really captured the Nigerian culture and the spirit of the people. I really loved the characters especially Yejide. I sometimes felt as if could not relate to the their struggles and at times I could not understand why or how fast their relationship deteriorated. Overall, this was an enjoyable read. I am looking forward to reading more of Adebayo's books. Put this on your TRL!...more

review: Believe the hype! "The Immortalists" was one of those books that was all over my Goodreads and Bookstagram page (P.S. follow me on Instagram  @BookOf Believe the hype! "The Immortalists" was one of those books that was all over my Goodreads and Bookstagram page (P.S. follow me on Instagram  @BookOfCinz  #ShamelessPlug ) and I felt everyone was reading this book except me, so in an effort to not be left behind I caved to the hype and I am happy I did! While the title and blurb makes the book seems like it is a magical mystical genre, it is actually extremely realistic and relatable. In the summer of 1979 four Gold children found a Fortuneteller who told them the exact date of their death, how each child took that information is explored in the book- great premise right?!I love a book with a great premise and Chloe Benjamin delivered in this area and then some. I honestly loved how she explored how each Gold child lived their life based on the knowledge of their "impending" death. I loved the four characters and how we see their development through the years. What I really appreciated was the exploration of how you can live life fearlessly. This is definitely a must read for me! A great read to start your February. ...more

my rating: 1 of 5 stars2 of 5 stars3 of 5 stars4 of 5 stars5 of 5 starsadd to shelves
review: When I was in high school I got a summer job at the local bookstore in Jamaica. During my time there I devoured every single John Grisham book that waWhen I was in high school I got a summer job at the local bookstore in Jamaica. During my time there I devoured every single John Grisham book that was on the shelf. For that entire summer I was enveloped in the world of John Grisham and it was one of my best summers. From then on, I promised myself that one thing I would say boldly and proudly was, "I've read all of John Grisham's novels!" It is with this in mind that it pains my heart to write this .... This novel didn't feel or read like a John Grisham novel. Yes it had the usual strong premise, its clear a lot of research went into the book, it was thrilling and enjoyable but overall it didn't read and felt like a John Grisham novel. There was period of the book where I felt like the story veered from a thrilling heist to a Mills & Boons novel and it kept going back and forth like that for a good chunk of the plot. Don't get me wrong, there is nothing wrong with a little romance but it felt forced and very un-John Grisham like...I really wanted to love this book because I get so excited when I see a new release from one of my favorite Authors but this one really felt flat on so many levels. I applaud him for trying something new but this didn't work for me. I would still encourage a John Grisham fan to read this and give me their thoughts. ...more

First book by Oakley and I am impressed at how wonderful a job she did with this noveAn endearing, heart-warming, delightful read, 4 wonderful stars! First book by Oakley and I am impressed at how wonderful a job she did with this novel. The plot centers around two main characters- Jubilee Jenkins, a young woman with the rarest of allergies, she is allergic to human touch. Then there is Eric who is failing at fatherhood and barely holding things together. Put these two together and you get the most loveable read. I loved the premise, even though I read something like it in  Everything, Everything  this still works well here. The characters are loveable, they possess depth, they are so human and I loved that Oakley really showed how much they are struggling individually. I am surprised how much I loved this book, and how well everything worked together. My only negative is that the end felt insanely rushed, Oakley tied things up a bit too nicely for my taste and I would have loved to see a bit more exploration to the end instead of the rushed ending we were given. Overall, a delightful read. ...more

Without memory, each night is the first night, each morning is the first morning, each kiss and touch are the first.""The argument goes that if the past as uncertain effect on the present, there is no need to dwell on the past. And if the present has little effect on the future, present actions need not be weighed for their consequences. Rather, each act is an island in time, to be judged on its own." MIND. BLOWN. Honestly, my brain is still reeling from reading this book.I am one of those persons who believes in time. I believe in reaching on time, being on time and respecting other people's time. Time is the only thing we cannot get back or get more of, which means it is something we should value and respect. Imagine how shattered my world is after reading this book.Lightman's writes stories showing the numerous ways we can look at time- as linear, as a circle, as disjointed, as three dimensional, endless, etc... Lightman opens our world to the numerous possibilities and make a case that time is measure how we see fit. This book really blew me away, it made me question how I look at time and how I currently live my life. While it is only 150 pages long, it deep and profound. This definitely should be one of the books you read before 30. MUST. READ. ...more

my rating: 1 of 5 stars2 of 5 stars3 of 5 stars4 of 5 stars5 of 5 starsadd to shelves
review: There is something about words. In expert hands, manipulated deftly, they take you prisoner. Wind themselves around your limbs like spider silk, and wThere is something about words. In expert hands, manipulated deftly, they take you prisoner. Wind themselves around your limbs like spider silk, and when you are so enthralled you cannot move, they pierce your skin, enter your blood, numb your thoughts. Inside you they work their magic. My bookish friend sent me this book because she thought I would enjoy it. Prior to getting this book I had it on my shelf for a long time, hoping to get around to it. Having it on my physical shelf, staring me in my face meant I had to pick it up. I love books about books. I love books about readers, writers and publishers. I thought for sure I would absolutely adore this book and I did, for the first 200 pages... then my adoration started to wane. The book had so much promise I literally sighed with satisfaction when I started reading it, I already predicted this would end up on my "absolute favorite" shelf. Needless to say, after the first 200 pages things sort of went downhill for me. I began to feel a bit creeped out, the meandering and pacing of the plot made me lose interest a couple of time. I no longer had any interest in the twins and their plight- everything just unravelled for me.I really wanted to give this a higher ratings but 3 will have to do. I have to say, these two quotes contained in this  really spoke to my soul as a reader. I have always been a reader; I have read at every stage of my life and there has never been a time when reading was not my greatest joy. And yet I cannot pretend that the reading I have done in my adult years matches in its impact on my soul the reading I did as a child.  ...more

review: Elizabeth Strout's novels take me on a spiritual and emotional journey and this book was no different. There is something so profound in the way StrouElizabeth Strout's novels take me on a spiritual and emotional journey and this book was no different. There is something so profound in the way Strout writes that takes my breath away and leave me filled with so many different emotions. I feel like Olive Kitteridge is part of each of us and what she faces is something we will most likely have to face (assuming we live for a long time). Strout forces us to really look at ourselves and our lives and the way we treat other people in the most subtle of ways. Strout explores in-depth what is like to get old, have an empty nest and loneliness. What really resonated with me was the many layers to Olive Kitteridge, and we it from her stories and how she is mentioned by other people. Elizabeth Strout can do no wrong and with Olive Kitteridge its no different. I love this collection of short stories. Definite must read. ...more

Now that I got that preamble out of the way, let's focus on The Goldfinch I've had this book on my radar since it was released back in October 2013. I was up for a challenge of reading a long book, but I am not sure I was prepared for this book. It was entirely too much and a little too depressing. The subject that was covered was enough to get the most well-adjusted adult depressed and thinking the worse of the world. Not only was it a difficult read because of the murder, but also Alexandria's memoir and what she went through growing up. In some ways I wish this was more about her story but I understand how both stories supports each other. Reading this book, my heart broke from the writer and what she went through growing up and how her family reacted. The only draw back for me was how the information was presented, it felt a little all over the place. Maybe its because I honestly just wanted to hear Alexandria's story, and that was scattered all over the book, at sometime I became a little impatient. title: Anything Is Possible        (Amgash, #2)
author: Strout, Elizabeth*
my rating: 1 of 5 stars2 of 5 stars3 of 5 stars4 of 5 stars5 of 5 starsadd to shelves
review: What can I say about Elizabeth Strout's writing that's not been said before? There are writers/storytellers and then there is Elizabeth Strout. It is What can I say about Elizabeth Strout's writing that's not been said before? There are writers/storytellers and then there is Elizabeth Strout. It is clear she is blessed by God Almighty with the gift of writing and storytelling and I for one consider myself blessed to be able to delve into her literary world. Now that my fan-girling is over, let me  the book. "Anything is Possible" really is the epitome of how short stories should be written. While you don't have to read the first novel "My Name Is Lucy Barton" to fully appreciate this follow-up, it would help. I love how the stories are like loose leave green tea that comes together seamlessly in the end. I actually love how strong and well developed each character and story is, even though it just goes on for 30 pages- if so much. As usual, these words come to mind whenever I read a Elizabeth Strout novel:Poignant SharpGentleThought-provoking Mind-blowing Rich UnderstatedWhile the book is short in pages, it is rich and overflowing in content. The novel for me reads like an on-going “Humans of New York” blurb and I loved that. The narrative is realistic, emotional, melancholy, moving, very stripped down and organic. I am in awe of Strout’s rich language and how she is able to move a plot along with so little words. Two of my favorite quotes from this book are: "A complaining woman was like pushing dirt beneath the fingernails of God""The HIT-THUMB THEORY... one summer hammering tiles down hard, he'd discovered that if you hammered your thumb by mistake, there was a split second when you thought: Hey, this isn't so bad, considering how hard I was hit. And then- after that moment of false, bewildered, and grateful relief- came the crash and crush of real pain." ...more

title: Behind Her Eyes
author: Pinborough, Sarah*
my rating: 1 of 5 stars2 of 5 stars3 of 5 stars4 of 5 stars5 of 5 starsadd to shelves
review: Slow claps... slow claps... Yes Sarah Pinborough, you win with this one You have to admire an author who legit doesn't know where a book/premise is g Slow claps... slow claps... Yes Sarah Pinborough, you win with this one You have to admire an author who legit doesn't know where a book/premise is going but they have the imagination to see it through. Sarah Pinborough, you win with this one yes. I honestly cannot stop laughing at the plot, the "plot twist" along with the extremely shaky premise that Pinborough came up with.I am giving this book a 4 stars because I honestly think Pinborough deserves it for the following reasons:1. She really committed to that premise and the plot line and I admire her commitment2. For convincing her publisher/editors that this premise makes sense3. For getting me to not only read the novel, but actually enjoy and "buy into" the premise 4. For being entirely brave with her imagination. It is really hard to  this novel without giving away some spoilers and I think in a way this works in the favor of Pinborough because if y'all found out the spoiler you probably would:A. Be intriguedB. Die laughing C. Just not read it. What I will say is, this is NOT another Gone Girl , please do not make that comparison. It does however entertain you, keeps you on the edge of your pages and one thing is for sure, it is not lacking in imagination. Honestly, I kind of saw the twist coming but I just could not believe that would be it, which made me stick with the book to the end. I recommend this read because it honestly blew my mind and makes me laugh out loud every time I think of the premise. Also, I need someone to discuss this book with. title: The Book of Joy: Lasting Happiness in a Changing World
author: Dalai Lama XIV
my rating: 1 of 5 stars2 of 5 stars3 of 5 stars4 of 5 stars5 of 5 starsadd to shelves
review: What a joyfully, deeply soul moving book this is. I enjoyed and learned every minute of reading this book. The Book of Joy is basically a conversationWhat a joyfully, deeply soul moving book this is. I enjoyed and learned every minute of reading this book. The Book of Joy is basically a conversation between the Dalai Lama and Archbishop Desmond Tutu about how you find joy or more specifically how as an individual you can be joyful in this world. The book was done as commemorative piece for the Dalai Lama’s 80th birthday. The two met in India for the celebration of their lives and to talk about Joy, led by the writer Douglas Abrahams. I have to admit that I do not know who Archbishop Desmond Tutu his or how instrumental he was in the apartheid movement. What I will say is, I learned so much about this Archbishop and its clear he is one joyful fellow. Aside from the profound, awe-inspiring wisdom doled out in this book, what I appreciated was how Abrahams uniquely captured the true spirit of these two individuals. Who knew the Dalai Lama and Archbishop Desmond Tutu were too big jokers who are constantly look for any moment to tease each other or create fun trouble? I thoroughly enjoyed how human these two Spiritual men were depicted and I think I related and learned a lot more based on how they were depicted. I also love that even though they are both from two religious backgrounds, they agreed on a lot. I will be putting into practice some of the tips Abrahams left us with, I think a lot can be gained from having a “God-eyes” view of a situation. As with a lot of things, practice is needed but I am up for the challenge. I have to make mention of the photos used in the book, they were all magically- whoever the photographer was clearly knows how to capture magic in one click. I leave you with some of my favorite quotes from this book.“Why be unhappy about something if it can be remedied? And what is the use of being unhappy if it cannot be remedied?”“Wherever you have friends that’s your country, and wherever you receive love, that’s your home.’”“A healthy perspective really is the foundation of joy and happiness, because the way we see the world is the way we experience the world. Changing the way we see the world in turn changes the way we feel and the way we act, which changes the world itself. Or, as the Buddha says in the Dhammapada, “With our mind we create our own world.”...more

title: The Sandcastle Girls
author: Bohjalian, Chris*
my rating: 1 of 5 stars2 of 5 stars3 of 5 stars4 of 5 stars5 of 5 starsadd to shelves
review: How do a million and a half people die with nobody knowing?- HOW?? I honestly don't know how to  this book, I have so much to say, I am so sad  How do a million and a half people die with nobody knowing?- HOW?? I honestly don't know how to  this book, I have so much to say, I am so sad and emotionally depleted after finishing this book. I cannot believe I have never heard about the Armenian Genocide until I picked up this book. I asked my friends if they knew about it and they've vaguely heard something about it. How do we not know more about the 1.5 million Armenians that died? Why isn't this common knowledge? See, that's the thing with loving the historical fiction, you know most is historical and just a little fiction. Yesterday I finished reading this book and I was so emotionally depleted I could not go do my usual evening run. My heart pained for the families, for all the men, women and children who died senselessly. It pained when I think about the magnitude of this genocide. Its akin to someone killing every single individual on the island of Trinidad and Tobago. When you think of it like that, it is unimaginable. Just imagine you wake up one day and 1.5million people were killed because of their background. So senseless. What is even more shocking is that this is now happening somewhere around the world. What was especially heart wrenching is that there were some Armenians who survived the genocide and then ended up in concentration camps. Can you imagine having your world ripped a part like that? Overall Chris Bohjalian ripped open my world with this book. I loved that he wrote about such a crucial piece of history that would remain hidden to someone people like me. A hard but necessary read.  "I was crying over the deaths of one and a half million people, and a civilization in eastern Turkey that had been reduced to a mountain of bones in the ginger sands of Der-el-Zor." ...more

It reminds me of a lot The Twelve Tribes of Hattie , I know, you are not supposed to compare books but they both were great reads. The Turner House is really not about the House itself, but of the people who lived in it- well some of the people that is. I really enjoyed the storytelling, the characters were relatable and they really pulled you into their lives. Imagine having 12 siblings- madness! At first the sheer number of children and their names were a bit overwhelming and at times I got mixed up and confused but Flournoy managed to narrow down and focus on key individuals and we learned more about their siblings from their POV. On one hand I wished we could have learned more from the other siblings but on another hand, Flournoy style helped in making the characters manageable. review: I was offered a copy of this book from the author in exchange for an unbiased - thanks for the book Kimelene. There is something about reading aI was offered a copy of this book from the author in exchange for an unbiased - thanks for the book Kimelene. There is something about reading a book that is set in a place you currently live in or visited once, you inevitably begin to feel like you are more a part of the story and the lives of the characters. Carr did an amazing job of really writing about what live if like for most Trinidadian and we get a brief look into the public health care system. Sans Espoir brings together the lives of six individual, all from various backgrounds who happen to be at a General Hospital in Trinidad. Carr carefully introduces us to each of the characters, we get a look into the most intimate parts of their lives leading up to the time when they arrive at the hospital. I really appreciated the background on each character but I wish the book was longer so we could have gotten a deeper exploration into these characters. I felt the shortness of the book led to plot being rushed and being a little unrealistic. I do have a great appreciation for Carr's writing because it is clear she is a great storyteller, I just wish she had given us more with this novel. title: The Shack
author: Young, William Paul
my rating: 1 of 5 stars2 of 5 stars3 of 5 stars4 of 5 stars5 of 5 starsadd to shelves
review: As an individual who constantly struggles with her relationship with God, Jesus and the Holy Spirit, "The Shack" definitely came at the moment when I As an individual who constantly struggles with her relationship with God, Jesus and the Holy Spirit, "The Shack" definitely came at the moment when I needed it the most. I didn't know exactly what the book was about before I started reading it, but I read a Reviewer who recommended it for persons who were feeling far from God. Needless to say, the last few weeks I haven't been feeling God's presence as strongly as I used to and I have been praying for a sign or something to get back into a deeper relationship with Him- then "The Shack" turned up in my newsfeed.I am not here to dispute if what happened to Mack is real or not, after reading "The Shack" I do not want to play judge. What I will say is everyone will experience this book based on where they are currently with their walk with God and what happened/is currently happening to them. For me, this book shook me to the core. It made me cry, laugh, left me awe, smiles, opened my spiritual world in so many ways. The most important take away from this book for me is the relationship factors that were discussed. I loved how we see God, Jesus and the Holy Spirit as approachable loving individuals we can all have a deep relationship. Too often I view God as this terrifying judge and jury just waiting to smite me, and that is truly not the case. Also, the Holy Spirit was always this fleeting wonder I could never wrap my mind around and after reading this book, I really got an appreciation for Him. Overall, this book is in my soul, it has refreshed my relationship with God and made Him more approachable and that in itself says a lot. Too often we get caught up with religion, institutions and we feel judged, that we are not living up to what is expected because we cant seem to reach that "perfection" that is required. We were made to love and have a deep relationship with God- this book really drove that point home for me. I have so much to say about this book and it is definitely one of those books I will keep re-reading. I wrap up with saying that this book really shook me when it made reference of worrying, how we live in the past and the future and when we do this, God isn't there, because He is present with us, we should remain present. Growing up my mother was as worrier and it is a habit I have been trying to shake because I know worrying does not help in any situation and reading that God made reference to worrying really spoke to me. This is a MUST READ for me. ...more

title: Hunger: A Memoir of (My) Body
author: Gay, Roxane*
my rating: 1 of 5 stars2 of 5 stars3 of 5 stars4 of 5 stars5 of 5 starsadd to shelves
review: The story of my body is not a story of triumph. This is not a weight-loss memoir. There will be no picture of a thin version of me, my slender body e The story of my body is not a story of triumph. This is not a weight-loss memoir. There will be no picture of a thin version of me, my slender body emblazoned across this book’s cover, with me standing in one leg of my former, fatter self’s jeans.....Mine is not a success story. Mine is, simply, a true story.... Instead, I have written this book, which has been the most difficult writing experience of my life, one far more challenging than I could have ever imagined. To dates I have read everything Roxane Gay wrote, even her last tweet. Hunger remains one of the most difficult books I have had to read in a long time. Words fail. It is not often an author lays themselves bare for the world to see. It is not often an author show you their secrets, wounds and deepest innermost self. This hardly, if ever happens, and I for one am so proud to have read this memoir. I have so many feelings about this book and while she preface by saying this is not a book about triumph, I cant help but feel in a lot of ways it is. After finishing this book, I felt for Roxane Gay (yes I know she isn't looking my pity she said that at least 5 times in the book), but my heart pained for all her experience. This book is essential read for everyone, especially those who struggle with being empathetic. This is the new standard for ALL memoirs. If your memoir is not as real, poignant, bare, beautifully written, clever, insightful, brave, moving, and life changing as this, I don't want to read it. Gay has set the bar high what a real memoir is, and how memoirs should be written- this I wasn't surprised about- her writing is impeccable. Honestly, I could write a book on how beautiful this memoir is, but I encourage you, READ THIS, it will change your life in a lot of ways. Once again Roxane Gay takes us on a painful yet real journey. It will be difficult at times, but this is essential read.  MUST READ ...more

title: The Twelve Lives of Samuel Hawley
author: Tinti, Hannah*
my rating: 1 of 5 stars2 of 5 stars3 of 5 stars4 of 5 stars5 of 5 starsadd to shelves
review: Everything breaks if you hit it hard enough. The Twelve Lives of Samuel Hawley was really weird but also a very enjoyable read. First let me tell you Everything breaks if you hit it hard enough. The Twelve Lives of Samuel Hawley was really weird but also a very enjoyable read. First let me tell you why it is weird. It is this mix of Western, coming of age, small town, father daughter relationship, thriller, mystery and love story all mixed into one book. Yes, the book was a mix of all those genres and surprisingly it was very well done. I usually do not like books that are set in small town but Tinti had so many other things going on plot wise that I was thoroughly entertained. Samuel Hawley is a cat with twelve lives, he's been on the road/run from an early age, that was until he met Loo's mom, fell in love and decided to settle down. However, as with most criminals, their past lives will catch up with them. This book thoroughly explores a relationship a father has with his daughter and how they navigate the father's past mistakes. I honestly enjoyed reading this book and I think it had to do with the characters but also how the book was presented. We go back and forth between the present and the past. The past explores how Samuel Hawley came close losing his life, all of which were nail biting, random and often times a little hilarious. The present explores Loo's relationship with her dad, her falling in love and basically growing up. If you are in the mood for a coming of age, western, thriller, mystery or love story, this is the book for you. A must read for me. ...more

At first I was a little peeved at this book's title because I felt it was reinforces this new culture of "I don't give a F about anything". This is a culture I can not stand and I continuously roll my eyes when I see those Instagram, Facebook and Twitter post about how many "Fks" people don't give. I constantly ask, "why is this a thing?" and "what is so wrong about giving a F?"Needless to say, the title is very misleading, and it accomplished exactly what it set out to do, grab people's interest and let them purchase/read the book- good job Manson, you got me here. The book basically spoke about focusing our lives and caring about the things that need our attention, as opposed to draining our energy on mundane irrelevant things. It is about knowing what "fks" to give basically. While there is nothing grounding breaking in this book, it served as a good reminder of all the things we sometimes forget or take for granted. title: Born a Crime: Stories From a South African Childhood
author: Noah, Trevor
my rating: 1 of 5 stars2 of 5 stars3 of 5 stars4 of 5 stars5 of 5 starsadd to shelves
review: 4.5I absolutely loved everything about this book. I didn't know what to expect when I decided to read it, and Trevor Noah really gave me a history les4.5I absolutely loved everything about this book. I didn't know what to expect when I decided to read it, and Trevor Noah really gave me a history lesson, kept me laughing, made me cry a little and in general made in a huge fan of him. A lot of things he referenced about South Africa I could relate to growing up in Jamaica and I loved that. Three things that I learned that really shocked me were:1. Imagine your birth being a crime. Just take a moment to let that sink in. You were born a crime. Under the Apartheid system, your entry in the world is punishable by four years in prison for your parents. That honestly blew my mind in so many ways. It made me sad and angry. But I loved how Trevor and his Mom dealt with the situation. 2. In this book Trevor told us that as part of the Apartheid system people could apply to be white. People. Could. Apply. To. Be. White. There was a system in place where people could actually apply to be white. Again, let that sink in. As Trevor described, there was a pencil test where they would put a pencil in your hair and if it goes straight through you are white. CRAZY RIGHT?!!!!!! 3. Another thing I found fascinating was the fact that Chinese were classified as blacks because they didn't know how to classify them. However, because the Japanese had a lot more to offer to the Government they were classified as white. Wow.I love a book that makes me learn and opens my world and I think that's exactly what Trevor Noah did here. I have been recommending this book to everyone I meet because it is so relevant today. Apart from that, you were get an in-depth look into Trevor Noah's life growing up and trust me, that was a fun one. The only problem I had with this book was that it didn't cover how exactly he went to America and started hosting one of the most watched late night shows. I know I am asking for a lot and maybe he will cover all of that in his next book. Overall, this was an entertaining read and I think everyone should read it! ...more

I liked how original the idea and I could almost see Hutchison's thought process but I felt the editor did a bad job of making sure the concept stuck and was well executed. Don't get me wrong, the story starts of very strong, you are pulled in, creeped out, annoyed, frustrated and just DYING to find out what will become of these Butterflies. In some way you also want to know how did this Garden come about and what is the backstory of this Gardener. I think the main problem with the story was hearing it being told from Maya's perspective. Listen, this girl should be renamed Tangent because that's all she did while telling the story. At one point I almost wanted to scream "Maya answering the f-ing question! We don't want to go on another stupid journey with you that takes the plot no where!" Honestly, she was the most frustrating narrator I have read in awhile. She made me not care or want to find out what happened. I also didn't think the ending was realistic and it made me roll my eyes SOOOO hard! Really Hutchison?!!!! Overall, this book got under my skin that is a good and bad thing. I know for a fact Ill remember it and become annoyed again which in a way makes me want to tell you, read it! That way you can be annoyed with me. lol. ...more

I have so many things to say about this novel, it might not be coherent but neither was the book so please bear with me.1. Rent CANNOT be that expensive for you to submit yourself to such rules and regulations. Also, in this day and age with so many persons having a lot of things they don't need to impress people they don't like, I hardly see that minimalist living taking off. I did appreciate the author bringing to life the idea that we all have a lot of things we really don't need or use and we all could use a little minimalistic view in our lives. 2. As one er rightfully said, this was really a mix between "Gone Girl" and "Fifty Shades of Grey". Yes, a weird mix but it kinda sorta work in an insanely weird way. Granted, the fifty shades party wasn't badly written and wasn't enough so it ruined the book and made it totally trashy, I think it added nicely to the overall plot. 3. I started the book last night and I could not put it down. Honestly, I spent the entire day with my kindle glued to my hands just so I could finish it. It is a wild, insane, somewhat unbelievable right. You are going to be thrilled, mystified, annoyed, shocked and peeved in one go. I will admit, Delaney knows how to weave a twisty, turny tail and I loved every minute of it. I honestly could go on and on about this novel but I urge you to read it and let me know what you think. This is definitely a one to watch for this year's must read novels. ...more

title: Salt to the Sea
author: Sepetys, Ruta*
my rating: 1 of 5 stars2 of 5 stars3 of 5 stars4 of 5 stars5 of 5 starsadd to shelves
review: "This book is a work of historical fiction. The Wilhelm Gustloff is very real. The sinking of the Wilhelm Gustloff is the deadliest disaster in mariti"This book is a work of historical fiction. The Wilhelm Gustloff is very real. The sinking of the Wilhelm Gustloff is the deadliest disaster in maritime history, with losses dwarfing the death tolls of the famous ships Titanic and Lusitania. Yet remarkably, most people have never heard of it. An estimated 9,000 people were killed."Wow. This book left me speechless, it ripped my heart out and torn it up into a million pieces. No matter how many books I've read on the Nazi invasion my heart doesn't seem to stop hurting. So many suffered, so many future lost, so many families were split apart, so many children died- this was humanity at its worse. Ruta told the story of what four young adults went through during the Nazi invasion, how they ended up on the Wilhelm Gustloff and how their meeting will forever change each of there lives. This is YA genre like I have never seen it before. The characters were interesting, they all had so many interesting layers to them. Ruta really did her research with this book and it shows in the interesting construction of the plot and characters. I honestly cannot get over what an amazing book this is and how much I've learned. I am baffled that as an avid Historical Fiction reader I've never heard of Operation Hannibal or this ship's disaster. Thanks Rupta for writing about this, job well done. MUST. READ. ...more

review: Solid 3.5 This book kept popping up on my Instagram feed A LOT, mostly from some successful women I know and ladies around my age, so I decided to givSolid 3.5 This book kept popping up on my Instagram feed A LOT, mostly from some successful women I know and ladies around my age, so I decided to give it a go. I will say I learned a lot from this book, and Sandberg pointed out a lot of things that I currently do that might be impeding me in ways I did not know. So yes, the book was indeed an eye-opener, I had a lot of "ah ahhh" moments while reading. With that said, some areas I found she rambled a bit and other areas I could not relate to. Not to nit pick but hearing about that story of the lady who have her kids wear their school uniforms to bed to save 15mins in the morning really threw me of, I know it is a little shallow but I couldn't help but think, aren't these kids supposed to shower before going to school..... I digress...I think women of any age have a lot to gain by reading this book, it really makes you reflect on those missed opportunities or how we as women sometimes get in our own way. Sandberg definitely added to the conversation in a good way. I liked that she touched on the point of how so much is expected of women and how society places us in specific roles and if we try to break out of those roles we are considered not living up to the right expectations. A really relevant read. ...more

title: Shoe Dog: A Memoir by the Creator of Nike
author: Knight, Phil
my rating: 1 of 5 stars2 of 5 stars3 of 5 stars4 of 5 stars5 of 5 starsadd to shelves
review: This book moved me in ways I never thought possible. Just 25% in and I had to stop to tell everyone about it. I honestly cannot stop talking about howThis book moved me in ways I never thought possible. Just 25% in and I had to stop to tell everyone about it. I honestly cannot stop talking about how amazing this book is. This might just be the best memoir I have ever read, hands down. ...First let me say, while I do consider myself a runner, I am not a fan of NIKE, my go too brand for sneakers is ASICS because #RealRunnersWearAsics .I decided to give this book a go because I really like reading about how companies get started. I also subscribe to Ryan Holiday's reading list and this was on his list to read- I got curious and decided to give it a go. Best decision for the month of August. Before picking up this book, I've never heard of Phil Knight or anything related to him. After finishing this book, I must say, Phil Knight moved me to tears, motivated me, made me cry, inspired me, left me in awe, pissed me off a little but overall, Knight made me a believer in everything that is NIKE. I see a lot of myself in young Knight, how unsure he was about his place in life, how we knew he had a bigger calling and how he took the unbeaten track in life. I liked that he took the time to travel and gain a lot of insights he wouldn't have gained being in Oregon. I loved how honest he was about the struggle to build a business, how he remained true to himself against everything else. People see NIKE and a lot, including myself would not believe the struggle and fight it took to make it the brand it is today. I almost could not believe the pure fight Knight went through to make sure that company succeeded. At times I felt tired and like giving up when I read about the problems that came about especially that 25million customs bill. I felt there are times I would have thrown in the towel and call it a day, but Knight stuck through it and this is the real reason for the company's success. I admire this man and everything he's achieved. I liked reading about the history of NIKE, how he decided on the name even though he didn't love it. How he paid graphic artist $35USD to create a logo that had "motion" and ended up with the swoosh/tick. That tick is one of the most recognized logos in the world. I am currently working in advertising, so reading about a brand image that came from nothing to being world renowned was extremely interesting for me. I've learned so much from reading this memoir, I honestly think this book should be required reading in schools. You learn about character, entrepreneurship, not giving up, taken the unbeaten road, believing in yourself and most of all- just doing it. Just do it. MUST READ...more

I was a little taken aback that Whitehead portrayed it as an actually railroad. My main drawback for this book were the characters, I did not feel for Cora or Caesar. They evoked no form of empathy or concern, mid-way through the book Caesar disappeared and I felt nothing. I would have preferred if the characters were strong and commanded my emotions. title: Dew Angels
author: Schwapp, Melanie*
my rating: 1 of 5 stars2 of 5 stars3 of 5 stars4 of 5 stars5 of 5 starsadd to shelves
review: Updated January 31, 2019Dew Angels is Melanie Schwapp’s debut novel. Dew Angels follows the life of Nola Chambers, Jamaican girl born into a family a Updated January 31, 2019Dew Angels is Melanie Schwapp’s debut novel. Dew Angels follows the life of Nola Chambers, Jamaican girl born into a family and community who thinks having dark skin is an offense and proceeds to treat Nola as such. The community of Redding in Jamaica prides itself on its “light-skinned” people, so much so, Nola stuck out like a sore thumb and she was made to not forget it by those around us. A coming of age novel, we meet Nola at age thirteen trying to navigate a world where her sister gets preferred treatment, where her father treats her less than and her mother is mute and turns a blind eye to all these things happening to her. Nola’s world begins to open up when her school principal places her into a study group with Dahlia and Delroy. Their bond begins to grow stronger than they expected with each day they spend together doing school work. While Dahlia’s Mother Merlene is viewed by the community of a woman of ill-repute, Nola cannot help but admire how close Dahlia is to her mother. Dahlia’s household is the one that Nola longs for they embody the relationship Nola wants to have with her Mom. Things take a turn for the worse when Nola is seeing leaving Merlene’s establishment.Melanie Schwapp wrote a character that is haunting, resilient, a fighter, and the overall embodiment of a true Jamaican woman- Nola is definitely one character I will always remember. The book takes us on an unforgettable journey, for at least then years of Nola’s life. We see her face challenges, defeat, loss of love but we also see her grow and fight back in the most beautiful way. I went through a range of emotions reading this book from anger, to disbelief to joy. I cannot stress how much I love this book- I highly recommend this book. 2017This book is near and dear to my heart, because my friend's Mom wrote this book and I received a signed copy. With that said, I was a little nervous to read the book because I felt like I had to like it, added to that my friend told me how great the book was. In the end I have to admit- I absolutely ADORED  Dew Angels  Dew Angels is a story centered around Nola- a Jamaican girl born into a family who thinks having dark skin is an offense and proceeds to treat Nola as such. I would classify this as a coming of age novel as we see how Nola progresses from being a victim to overcoming in every area of her life. Melanie Schwapp wrote a character that is haunting, resilient, a fighter, and the overall embodiment of a true Jamaican woman- Nola is definitely one character I will always remember.I am always a fan of book that perfectly captures life in Jamaica, especially ones that contains colorful and believable characters. I laughed out loud, cried, and smiled having read this novel. What a brilliant read. Must read in my book!...more

title: The Poisonwood Bible
author: Kingsolver, Barbara
my rating: 1 of 5 stars2 of 5 stars3 of 5 stars4 of 5 stars5 of 5 starsadd to shelves
review: Updated August 13, 2018  Reading this book was like visiting some old friends and catching up. It was a really nostalgic read for me, and I thoroughl Updated August 13, 2018  Reading this book was like visiting some old friends and catching up. It was a really nostalgic read for me, and I thoroughly enjoyed Kingsolver's writing in this novel. The Poisonwood Bible is about the Price family who is on a mission trip to Congo during the 1950s. The Dad, Nathan Price is a Minister who sets out to saving souls for Christ and baptizing everyone who comes in his path. There are a lot of cultural, spiritual and political things in play that hinders Price from achieving his goal- including his family. What absolutely loved about this novel was the writing. The book is told from the POVs of the mother and the daughters in the family. It is uncanny how distinct each voice it and I thoroughly appreciated that. This is a solid five star novel for me.  July 12, 2016 It took me 9 days to finish this book. NINE DAYS. I feel like I just finished running a marathon. I am exhausted, emotional, annoyed, happy, unhappy, angry, vindicated, tired- I am feeling just about every emotion after finishing this book. Like running a marathon, there were times where I felt I would never finish this book. There were times where I just didn't want to continue reading, but Kingsolver is a master storyteller, it was impossible to stop once I started. I have to say, Kingsolver's character development and use of varying POVs is impeccable. I am amazed at how she goes between four characters and each have a very distinct voice. At first I thought all of this would falter coming to the end but these characters are very consistent. I would go out on the limb and say, I have never read a book with such strong character POVs. I honestly loved this book. I think I rushed through some of the parts because I just wanted to be over, but overall, this is a must read. Also, how am I JUST finding this book when it seems half my Goodreads friends read it already! Late to the party much. MUST. READ....more

What I will say is, this book is not for everyone. If you are grieving this book will resonate with you. If you've ever lost someone, this book will hit the spot and you will find yourself having a lot in common with Didion. I do have an appreciation for the book even though I haven't lost anyone (KNOCK ON ALL WOOD). I really felt for Didion in ways I didn't think possible. The writing will take a little getting used to, but you forgive it because this is grief at its rawest form. I like learning something new or having a thought provoked while reading. What really stuck with me was Didion explaining that people who are grieving are not diagnosed as having a psychological problem because they are expected to "overcome" or "get through it", but why isn't grief studied and looked at more in-depth? Is it because everyone grieves differently? Is it because we are expected to go through it and come out "normal"? - yes, I really thought about this. I wouldn't say I enjoy reading this book, but I am definitely happy I read it. ...more

review: This book is a hard one to read and . It took me a while to plough through because each time I picked up the book, I would be reading about anotThis book is a hard one to read and . It took me a while to plough through because each time I picked up the book, I would be reading about another senseless death. It is such a heart-breaking read, and I can relate to Younge's feelings of wanting to SCREAM over how senseless these deaths were. What totally got me was Younge saying that he didn't go with the specific date because of the 10 murders but he could have chosen ANY day and the results would have been the same. CRAZY. That blew my mind, how is it possible that this is happening and no one is paying any attention to it? While I liked the book, I think Younge may have been a bit too ambitious and kinda bit off more than he can chew. I felt the presentation of the data wasn't as seemless as I wanted it to be. Some chapters were entirely too long and the others were entirely too short. This is an eye opener, and required reading. ...more

my rating: 1 of 5 stars2 of 5 stars3 of 5 stars4 of 5 stars5 of 5 starsadd to shelves
review: "You cannot build a reputation on what you are going to do""Fac, si facis. (Do it if you’re going to do it.)""He knew that urgent and important were n"You cannot build a reputation on what you are going to do""Fac, si facis. (Do it if you’re going to do it.)""He knew that urgent and important were not synonyms."Wow.... Wow. I was actually blown away by this book and Holiday's research before writing this book. I usually finish a book in 2-3 days but this book had me pausing and thinking about every line I read. I wrote and highlighted half the book and answered the questions posed in some instances. I treated this like a work book, I wanted to learned and get as much from this book as I can. I am usually weary of books like this. I think after reading Malcolm Gladwell's books I kinda think he is a the bar and to read anything else would be a waste of my time. Holiday sure proved me wrong on that point. I love when I can pick up a book a learn something life changing. For instance, Holiday spoke about how we sometimes talk about a goal so much the brain basically think we achieved it so we end up not pursuing said goal because in our mind, we already accomplished what we sent out to do. I see myself doing that time and time again. Reading that particular tidbit was a wake up call for me. I really loved this book and I see myself re-reading it in the future. I think this book should be read by everyone no matter their stage in life. Must read. ...more

I was as if all the detective/crime novel cliches were wrapped in this one book, here goes:- Cop transfers to a different city after some life-changing event at other job- Cop wants to prove herself - Murder happens to high society member- Supervisor starts micro-managing cop - Cop gets suspended for not walking the line - Cops still goes on to investigate murder on her own- Cop solves murder but is then confronted by murderer - Cops gets rescued, wakes up in hospital - Cop celebrates victory.... Sounds familiar? Well that is exactly what happened in this book- I summed the book up in those 9 lines. I could not get over how ordinary this book was. title: Sabga: A Will And A Way
author: Brereton, Bridget
my rating: 1 of 5 stars2 of 5 stars3 of 5 stars4 of 5 stars5 of 5 starsadd to shelves
review: 3.5 When I moved to Trinidad and Tobago, I was told that the Syrians basically own the island. The name Sabga was mentioned again and again both in po3.5 When I moved to Trinidad and Tobago, I was told that the Syrians basically own the island. The name Sabga was mentioned again and again both in positive and negative light. It is with this background that I jumped at the opportunity to read Anthony Sabga's autobiography. I am a sucker for a great rags to riches story and "A Will and A Way" takes you on a journey of success. Imagine moving to a country where you do not know the language, where you have to depend on everyone, where you are uneducated in a society with less than 100 people from your homeland- that alone is enough to send me into depression. Not Anthony Sabga. What I loved most about this book was that it was unashamed in showing you how many times Sabga actually failed. You got a realistic look into what it was like doing business in the 60s and just how a little out of the box thinking carried you a long way. Granted, this story was told from Anthony's point of view so some of it might be a little fiction but who am I to judge. What I didn't like was the layout/how the book was narrated. I felt like the authors/researchers had a lot to say but they didn't know how to present it. They also didn't know what to do with all the information they received so at points they threw a lot of information and at other points a whole situation or problem was summed up in two lines. Maybe I am nit picking here, but I felt there were so many ways they could have presented the information but they erred on the side of easy and most convenient.Overall, I really enjoyed this book mainly because of the historical background in doing business in Trinidad, the history the Syrians on the island and how motivating the overall message is. If you are planning to do business in Trinidad this is definitely a go too book. If you like a great rags to riches story, this will pique your interest. ...more

title: Small Great Things
author: Picoult, Jodi*
my rating: 1 of 5 stars2 of 5 stars3 of 5 stars4 of 5 stars5 of 5 starsadd to shelves
review: This was an uncomfortable book to read and I am sure it was extremely uncomfortable for Jodi to write. This is a book about racism written by a white This was an uncomfortable book to read and I am sure it was extremely uncomfortable for Jodi to write. This is a book about racism written by a white woman. Yes... talk about difficult and uncomfortable all rolled into one. Jodi managed to write a gripping story, you were totally enthralled the entire time you were reading. So many emotions will awake in you- anger, annoyance, grief, pity, triumph, vindication. As far as plot, character development and themes are concern, this is a sold story. I, for one, was a little ummm nervous that Jodi picked this topic to write about. Some will say, is this a story for her to tell? Shouldn't someone else be telling this story? But, after reading her Author's note, I can see why she decided to tackle such a difficult topic and I admire her courage and bravery. She did a fine job. I just cannot shake that feeling that maybe, just maybe it wasn't her story to tell....I could be wrong, but let me know what you think....more

title: The Woman in Cabin 10
author: Ware, Ruth*
my rating: 1 of 5 stars2 of 5 stars3 of 5 stars4 of 5 stars5 of 5 starsadd to shelves
review: I wish everyone would stop comparing every psychological thriller to "Gone Girl". Seriously, can we as a literary community come together and decide tI wish everyone would stop comparing every psychological thriller to "Gone Girl". Seriously, can we as a literary community come together and decide to let each novel stand on their own merit without the extra pressure of "Gone Girl".... Thanks!With all of that said, I actually did like "The Woman in Cabin 10". This book was reminiscence of those past Whodunnit books, particularly Agatha Christie. I loved that it was set in a confined space (a ship) with a limited amount of people which makes the read even more entertaining. Also, Ware kept the suspension and tension level going throughout the book. Very rarely you find an author who is able to keep the suspense going throughout the book and not wait until 75% in for the build up. What I could not stand was the main character Lo, she was a little annoying for my taste. I found myself rolling my eyes during some of her moments. I also didnt like that Ware didnt explore some of the other passengers on the boat in an effort to keep the guessing going. Great work overall, I really did not have a clue who the suspect was until the very end! ...more

author: Hawley, Noah*
my rating: 1 of 5 stars2 of 5 stars3 of 5 stars4 of 5 stars5 of 5 starsadd to shelves
review: 3.5 So I had this on my "to-read" and "2016 books to read" book shelf. I almost didn't read it because I saw this  below:"A pleasant bit of pred3.5 So I had this on my "to-read" and "2016 books to read" book shelf. I almost didn't read it because I saw this  below:"A pleasant bit of predictable nothingness. The setup is preposterous. Every cardboard character acts exactly as expected, from hero to villain. Every cliché drops into place. "Now, which sane person would want to waste their time reading a book that is described as "predictable nothingness"? Needless to say, I had to find out exactly what this "predicatable nothingness" was all about. I honestly loved this book and I was happy I didn't fall for that  because I would have been missing out on a really riveting story. Hawley could write. Hawley is a storyteller. I could sucked into this whole drama to the point where I skipped gym just so I could finish. This is not the usual way one would tell a story, especially one about a plane crash. You'd expect to hear from the victims before the crash, except you heard about their stories after which really fascinated me. I loved the back stories on all the characters and how the plot progressed really fascinated me. This honestly was an enjoyable read. I do recommend adding this to your 2016 Summer list! ...more

title: Commonwealth
author: Patchett, Ann
my rating: 1 of 5 stars2 of 5 stars3 of 5 stars4 of 5 stars5 of 5 starsadd to shelves
review: Solid 4.5 I devoured this book, I absolutely could not get enough of the characters and storyline. I have been in a horrible reading slum, falling 10 Solid 4.5 I devoured this book, I absolutely could not get enough of the characters and storyline. I have been in a horrible reading slum, falling 10 books behind on my reading goal because most of the books I end up reading end up being underwhelming. Needless to say, Ann Patchett's "Commonwealth" knocked me off my feet and woke me up out of my slumber. I am such a fan of storyline that follows families over a number of years and Patchett did a spectacular job of tying these families together in the neatest most messiest bow ever. I don't want to give a lot away, but the story starts when a DA shows up randomly to a cop's daughter christening and what happened after will blow your mind.A genuinely fun, gripping and interesting read. A totally different feel from Bel Canto but if you loved that book you will definitely enjoy this one. Read it, it is worth the hype!...more
